awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Microbial Friends and Foes: Towards a Synthesis of Interspecific Interactions
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to Cornell University, located in Ithaca, NY, will support the training of 12 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2019-2021.  The program focuses on host-microbe interactions and is hosted by the Cornell Institute of Host-Microbe Interactions and Disease.  Students will be trained in concepts, research questions, and experimental approaches central to understanding microbial interactions with eukaryotic hosts.  REU participants will obtain an immersive research experience through development, implementation and analysis of an independent research project, weekly seminars, and peer group discussions.  Strong emphasis will be placed on the synthesis of concepts explaining microbial interactions across diverse systems.  Orientation activities will include workshops devoted to research ethics, electronic database literacy, use of science citation software, and building science communication skills.  Participants will receive mentoring in professional development focused on planning for graduate school.  Recruitment will focus on students with limited access to research opportunities, and undergraduates from groups underrepresented in science are encouraged to apply. Applications will be collected through a web portal and participants will be selected in a two-step review process by the program selection committee and potential mentors. Acceptance will be based on academic record, research performance, and motivation for future outstanding research in biology. Assessment measures will include entry and exit interviews, student self-assesment, and the REU common assessment tool.  

It is anticipated that a total of 36 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained.  Students will learn how research is conducted by performing research which can be presented at scientific conferences or contribute to publications. Participants will gain knowledge and skills for applying to graduate school and careers in science.

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program.  Career paths of participants will be tracked after the program.  Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system.  More information about the program is available by visiting cihmid.cornell.edu/reu-mff, or by contacting the PIs (Dr. Teresa Pawlowska at tep8@cornell.edu and Dr. Tory Hendry at th572@cornell.edu).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit. The overall scientific goal of the Microbial Friends & Foes (MFF) REU Summer Site, associated with the Cornell Institute of Host-Microbe Interactions and Disease (CIHMID), was to train undergraduate students in the concepts, research questions, and experimental approaches central to understanding microbial interactions with eukaryotic hosts. Over the course of five years, 25 research programs from across departments and colleges at Cornell University hosted 44 students. MFF student research projects were devoted to various aspects of microbial interactions with eukaryotic hosts, including evolutionary dynamics, ecological determinants, and molecular mechanisms.


Within the first week of the program, each student prepared a brief research proposal reviewed by the program PIs. To make sure that all students were equally prepared for research activities, the MFF program included sessions on The Scientific Method, How to Write a Research Proposal, How to Read Scientific Literature, Data Management and Laboratory Notebooks, and Scientific Presentations. MFF students also participated in a campus-wide annual Symposium on Ethics in Science.


To complement research activities, students were involved in weekly Synthesis Panels in which they discussed research projects, identified overarching conceptual themes and synthesized them in group presentations. Each year, faculty hosts developed and presented a series of 8 lectures devoted to Theoretical and Practical Aspects of Host-Microbe Biology. A Workshop in R Programming was offered annually to MFF participants by one of the host labs. At the conclusion of the program, REU students reported their research findings in both poster and oral presentations. Results of several MFF projects were either published or are being prepared for publication with REU students as co-authors.


Broader Impacts of the Work. Broader impact goals of the MFF REU program were to: (1) involve Biology undergraduates from groups underrepresented in science, (2) prepare students to apply to graduate school and advance their careers in science, and (3) train students in how to conduct research, acquire technical skills for research, and explore biology more deeply by being engaged in research. To address these goals, the MFF REU was advertised through a program website, e-mailing fliers to over 500 life science departments in colleges across the country, including minority-serving institutions, and social media. Between 110 and 390 applications were received each year. Applications were reviewed by the two co-PIs. Preference was given to students representing: (1) minorities underrepresented in science and (2) colleges with limited opportunities to conduct research, and (3) first generation college students. Bundles of 3-7 preselected applications were presented to faculty hosts for final selection. Participants identified with one or more of the following diverse groups: underrepresented minority (75%), students from small colleges with limited access to research experiences (50%), and/or first-generation college students (45%). Participants received training in research skills as well as professional skills to prepare for graduate school and careers in science.  Surveys of participants showed that students gained valuable skills and felt better prepared and driven to continue in scientific research. Of graduated REU interns from the program, 77% have gone on to graduate school or scientific careers.
